featured.text: In the 1950s, flip-flops became popular in the United States as soldiers returning from occupied Japan brought zōris home.
Modern flip-flops derive from Japanese zōris, which were often worn with socks dividing the big toe from the rest, and were typically made of rice straw.

definition.zh_def: 一種日本傳統的草鞋，通常由草或其他天然材料製成，常用於室內或戶外。
definition.en_def: A type of traditional Japanese sandal, typically made from straw or other natural materials, commonly worn indoors or outdoors.
definition.example: He wore zōris to keep his feet cool during the hot summer days.
